Storage

Durable, highly available, and massively scalable cloud storage

1RMB Trial Buy Now

Azure Storage is a kind of highly durable, available and scalable cloud storage that you can access anytime, anywhere.

We charge customers Azure Storage space fees according to the storage capacity, number of storage transactions (number of read and write operations performed in the storage) and data already transmitted.

Storage is divided into five types:

Block Blobs: Block Blobs are a cost-effective, scalable method that can be used for reliably storing mass Blob data. Typical instances include: data sharing, mass data and backup.

Files: Files allows the VM of Azure Data Center to install shared document systems by SMB agreement, and access the document system via the standard Windows file API. The virtual machine can be connected to these document systems simultaneously, permitting you to easily share permanent data between different roles and instances. You can also access your data using Windows file API or document REST API.

Page Blobs and Disk: Page Blobs provide block storage for random access and frequent updating and optimization. Thanks to high performance, durability and reliability, it can be used as the permanent disk of the VM in Azure.

Table: Table is a kind of highly scalable and readily available NoSQL Database. These provide storage-based key values for structured data and semi-structured data.

Queues: Queues provide a reliable message transfer system used to plan asynchronous tasks, and realizes permanent message transfer.

In addition, we provide four redundant storage levels:

Locally Redundant Storage (LRS): We maintain multiple copies of data in the same region so as to provide high durability.

Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS): we asynchronously provide extra data durability through replication between two regions hundreds of miles apart in the same territory. In the two regions, we maintain multiple copies of the data.

Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage (RA-GRS): in addition to GRS services, we provide read-only access to the storage account in the secondary region (which has the final version consistent with data in the primary storage system). When the storage account in the primary region is not available, customers can use this service to access the data.

Zone Redundant Storage (ZRS): In addition to storage of three copies like LRS, the ZRS space replicates data asynchronously between data centers of one or two regions, so as to improve the durability of LRS.

Azure Managed Disk is a new and recommended disk storage product used for Azure Virtual Machines, enabling permanent data storage. Multiple Managed Disks can be used for every virtual machine. Managed Disks provide two types of lasting storage options: premium Managed Disk and standard Managed Disk.

If you’re interested in the pricing details of Non-Managed Disk, please refer to the Non-Managed Disk and Page Blob pricing details page.

Premium Managed Disk

Premium Managed Disk, based on high-performance solid state drive (SSD), aims to support I/O intensive workloads, with extremely high throughput and low delay. With the help of Premium Managed Disk, we can set a permanent disk and configure its size and performance characteristics.

The total expenses of Premium Managed Disk depends on the disk size and quantity, and is subjected to the outgoing data transmission. The disk size provides different input/output operations per second (IOP), throughput limits and monthly pricing per GB. We can select most appropriate options including storage size, IOP and throughput. We can add several permanent disks onto the VM and configure at most 64 TB of storage space to every VM. The disk throughput of every VM can reach up to 80,000 (input/output operations) and 1600 MB/second, with a read delay of less than 1 millisecond. Premium Managed Disk is supported by the sizes of the DS Series, DSv2 Series and FS Series VMs exclusively used for Premium Disks.

Operation and Data Transfer Pricing

If the transactions of Page Blob are not performed by Virtual Machines, billing is done by the transaction. For every transaction, a single operation shall be considered as write, read or delete for billing. If the size of the read or write is more than 64 KB, an extra read/write (IO) expense will be charged for every excess of 64 KB, and up to 15 IO are charged per transaction. If the size of a transaction is more than 1 MB [64 KB x (1 transaction + 15 IOs)], other IOs are not charged, irrespective of the size of transactions.

Data redundancy options

Locally Redundant Storage (LRS) Make multiple synchronous copies of data in a Data Center.
Zone Redundant Storage (ZRS) Store three data copies in multiple data centers in a region or across regions. Limited to Block Blob
Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS) The same as LRS, it also allows to store multiple asynchronous copies into the second data center hundreds of miles apart.
Read/Access Geo-Redundant Storage(RA-GRS) Just like GRS, this allows reading and accessing a second data center.

To learn more about the redundancy options and how to use these options to obtain high availability, please view the Azure Storage Space Replication Page. Please note, not all redundancy types are suitable for all storage types.

FAQ

Expand all

Common

  • If I only use the storage service a few days a month, is the cost prorated?

    Yes. The storage capacity is charged by the average data storage (with GB as the unit) per day within a month. For instance, if you’ve used 10 GB storage capacity continuously in the first half of the month, but haven’t used any storage capacity in the second half of the month, the average storage usage will be billed at 5 GB.

  • How do I know which data redundancy option I am using (see the text above)?

    You may select redundancy in creating storage accounts. After creation, you may view the redundancy by using Azure portal or the service management API.

Blob Storage

  • What is a Blob Storage account and what are the differences between this account and a general-purpose storage account?

    A Blob Storage account is exclusively used as the storage account for Blob Storage data, such that customers can assign access tiers according to the data access frequency in the account. A general-purpose storage account can be used for storing blob, files, disks, tables and queues.

  • Has the pricing of Block Blob in the general-purpose Storage account been changed?

    No. The pricing of Block Blob in the general-purpose Storage account hasn’t yet been changed. Please view the Block Blog Pricing page.

  • When viewing the Azure bill, how can we distinguish whether paying for Blob in the Blob Storage account or general-purpose Storage account is required?

    If “Hot” or “Cool” is in the resource name, this means that this expense is related to the Blob Storage account. For instance, if it’s “Standard IO - Cool Block Blob (GB)”, it means you used the Blob Storage account and need to pay for this account, while “Standard IO – Block Blob (GB)” is charged in relation to the Block Blob in the general-purpose Storage account.

  • What are “Hot” and “Cool” access tiers and how do we ascertain which one is to be used?

    In the Blob Storage account, we could set Blob’s access tier to “Hot” and “Cool”. The storage GB pricing increases in the sequence of “Cool” and “Hot” tier. The data access expense increases in the sequence of “Hot” and “Cool” tier. The “Hot” and “Cool” tiers are separately applied to data with almost no access and occasional access, and the availability of Service Level Agreement of these data has a lower requirement. If you don’t know the data access mode, it’s recommended that you use the “Hot” tier for at least one month in the beginning, then decide if it’s necessary to shift to “Cool” storage to save costs where applicable.

  • Is paying the data write expense of switching a Blob Storage account from “Cool” to “Hot” required?

    We will charge the data retrieval of the Blob Storage account when it’s switched from “Cool” to “Hot”. For instance, if the Blob Storage account has 100 GB data, when the account is switched from “Cool” to “Hot”, you will be charged with a data retrieval fee of 100 * ￥0.0657 = ￥6.57.

  • Is paying for data writes required when the Blob Storage account is switched from “Hot” to “Cool”?

    No. Paying for data writes is not required when your account is switched from “Hot” to “Cool”. If you write directly data into the “Cool” access tier of the Blob Storage account, only paying the data writing expense is required.

  • What is the charge for Geo-replication data transfer?

    When you write data into a GRS account, the data will be replicated into another Azure region. The Geo-replication data transfer charge refers to the bandwidth cost of replicating data to another Azure region.

Disk Storage

  • If I add the empty 100GB disk onto my virtual machine, will I be charged the entire 100 GB expense or just the cost of the storage space I used?

    If the empty 100GB disk is supported by a Premium Storage account, you will be charged for a P10 (128GB) disk. If you use any other types of Storage account, only the storage space for storing data written into the disk will be charged, irrespective of the allocated disk size.

  • Does the Service Level Agreement cover Premium Storage, the same as other Storage services?

    Yes. 99.9% read/write availability also applies to Premium Storage accounts.

Managed Disk

  • If I add an S10 or P10 disk to the virtual machine, will I be charged the cost of the total amount shown above or just the cost of the storage space I used?

    The allocated disks are charged at the same rate, irrespective of the disk space used.

  • The pricing shown is the monthly price. How do you charge if the Managed Disk is used less than one month?

    The charge uses the monthly pricing according to the hours and proportional cost.

File Storage

  • If I create sharing with a 5 TB limit, will I be charged for the entire 5 TB or just the cost of the storage space used?

    Only the storage space used is charged for, rather than the allocated limit.

Support & SLA

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

We guarantee that we can successfully process data reading requests from a read-access geo redundant storage (RA-GRS) account at least 99.99% of the time (99.9% for the Cool Access Tier), provided that we will retry in the secondary region from the data writing failure from the primary region.

We guarantee that we can successfully process data reading from locally redundant storage (LRS) and geo redundant storage (GRS) accounts at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the Cool Access Tier)

We guarantee that we can successfully process data writing requests into locally redundant storage (LRS) and geo-redundant storage (GRS) accounts and read-access geo redundant storage (RA-GRS) accounts at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the Cool Access Tier).

To learn more about the details of our Service Level Agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreements page.

The Managed Disk itself doesn’t provide a Service Level Agreement with financial support. The availability of a Managed Disk depends on the Service Level Agreement governing the basic storage used and the Virtual Machine it’s attached to. To learn more about the details of the Service Level Agreement of the Managed Disk, please visit the Managed Disk Service Level Agreements page.
